Label: AL rdfs:label@en
Definition: AL iao:0000115@en
Example: AL iao:0000112@en
Editors Note: AL iao:0000116@en

Label: organization
Definition: A group of people recognized as such by people outside the group.
Example: a political party, a homeowners association, a football team, a publisher, a government agency, an organized religion

Label: government organization
Definition: An organization which is the body of persons that constitutes the governing authority of a political unit
Example: The State of Florida is recognized as a government organization by the United States.  The government of the United States is recognized by other governments.  Note there is no "part of" relationship here.  Each is a government organization.

Label: company
Definition: A legal entity of associated persons created for a specific purpose, typically commercial, in which excess revenue may be distributed to the company's owners.
Example: BASF, The University of Phoenix, Facebook, Elsevier, Apple, Google, Amazon

Label: non-profit organization
Definition: A legal entity of associated persons created for a specific purpose, typically a mission, in which excess revenue is reinvested to serve the entity's mission
Example: Doctors Without Borders, Duke University, The American Medical Association

Label: informal organization
Definition: A group of people recognized as such by people outside the group. Without legal standing.
Example: A student club, a university committee, the VIVO Ontology Interest Group
Editors Note: There are many names associated with informal organizations, such as club, group, party, team, cell, task force, work group, interest group, meeting, roundtable, .  So far dispositions and qualities that would distinguish the entities with various names have not been formulated.

Label: organization part
Definition: An organization which exists as part of another organization.  Implies a part_of relationship to another organization
Example: The US Navy is an organizational part of the US Department of Defense.  The History Department is an organizational part of its college

Label: university
Definition: A disposition to award academic degrees and conduct research in a variety of academic disciplines
Example: The University of Bologna is an organization that has a university disposition
Editors Note: Some dispositions may well be functions -- the organization does not exist without it.

Label: association
Definition: A disposition to organize organizations or individuals along and industry or academic lines
Example: The American Medical Association; The AFL-CIO; The Institution of Railway Signal Engineers

Label: consortium
Definition: A disposition to organize organizations along industry or academic lines
Example: The Association of Research Libraries; The NIH Common Fund Metabolomics Consortium
Editors Note: The word "association" in english may mean many diffierent things.  Often consortiums have the word "association" in their title.

Label: service provider
Definition: A disposition to provide service with or without a fee
Example: A hospital has a service provider disposition to provide medical services to patients
Editors Note: We can expect to have many types of service provider dispositions

Label: laboratory service provider
Definition: A disposition to provide laboratory services.  In the US, organization parts in universities that have a disposition to provide laboratory services to others are called core laboratories
Example: The Interdisciplinary Center for Biotechnology Rsearch is a part of the university with a disposition to offer laboratory services to others
Editors Note: The word "core laboratory" may indicate that an organization has a disposition of laboratory services

Label: extension provider
Definition: A disposition to provide extension services, typically in agriculture.  Extension provides access to university research findings and advice to agriculturalists.
Example: Texas A&M Agrilife Extension is a part of the university with a disposition for providing agricultural exteension services
Editors Note: Extension is most commonly used to describe agircultural extension services.

Label: technology transfer
Definition: A disposition to create licenses for intellectual property for use by these beyond the creators
Example: The Duke Office of Licensing and Ventures has a technology transfer disposition

Label: philanthropy
Definition: A disposition to donate charitable causes, sometimes in the form of grants involving contracts regarding the use of the donated funds or effort.
Example: The Wellcome Trust, The Bill and Melinda Gates Foundation, The Sierra Club have dispositions of philanthropy

Label: funder
Definition: A disposition to fund proposals, often is response to a call for proposals by the entity with the funding disposition
Example: The National Institutes of Health (NIH) and The National Science Foundation (NSF) have funder dispositions

Label: health care service provider
Definition: A disposition to provider health care to humans
Example: A nurse has a disposition to provide health care servces

Label: hospital service provider
Definition: A disposition to provide hospital-based health care services to humans
Example: Mt. Sinai Hospital in New York has a disposition to provide hospital services

Label: archive
Definition: A disposition to collect, store, and provide access to inanimate material entities, and/or information content entitites
Example: The British Museum has a disposition to archive, particularly works of the United Kingdom
Editors Note: We might expect to have refinements of this disposition as special cases

Label: museum
Definition: A disposition to collect, store, and provide access to inanimate material entities in a facility
Example: The National Portrait Gallery is an art museum

Label: gallery
Definition: A disposition to display collected works from an archive
Example: The Color Factory in New York City is an art gallery
Editors Note: The distinction between an art gallery and and art museum has to do with the temporary nature of displays in galleries, as well as the common practice in galleries to sell art on display

Label: publisher
Definition: A disposition to publish information content entities
Example: Random House, Taylor and Francis, The American Pyschological Association, The University of California Berkeley has a disposition to publish

Label: research
Definition: A disposition to conduct research
Example: The Max Plank Institute, Northwestern University, CERN (the European Organization for Nuclear Research) have have a disposition to conduct research

Label: education
Definition: A disposition to teach, and provide experiential opprtunities for students
Example: a pre-school education program, a post-graduate education program, adult education programs all have education dispositions

Label: training
Definition: A disposition to train, and provide experiential opportunities for trainees
Example: A military training program, a flight school training program, a CPR training program all have dispositions to train

Label: research administration
Definition: A disposition to provide resources and oversight for those conducting research
Example: The Office of Research at a university typically does not conduct research, it has a disposition to administer research

Label: library
Definition: A disposition to provide library services
Example: The Library of Congress, the local public library, a university library allhave dispositions of library
Editors Note: Perhaps a function

Label: commerce
Definition: A disposition to sell things
Example: Google, Tesla, General Electric, BASF, AstraZeneca all have a disposition to sell things

Label: military
Definition: A disposition to engage in warfare
Example: The US Space Force, the Chinese Navy, and the Bolivian Army are example of organizations with miltary disposition
Editors Note: Perhaps a function

Label: religious
Definition: A disposition to engage in matters of spirtuality and faith
Example: The Catholic Church, a local synagogue, a mosque, a buudhist monestary have a relgisious disposition
Editors Note: Perhaps a function.

Label: governance
Definition: A disposition to provide governance
Example: A Board of Trustees, A Board of Directors, the Senate of the United States all have governing dispositions

Label: information address disposition
Definition: A disposition of an information content entity denoted by an address which has the purpose of responding to information inquiries
Example: Email addresses that begin help@ info@ contact@ often have information address address disposition

Label: billing address disposition
Definition: A disposition of an address to be used to receive bills
Example: Bills may be sent to Attn: Name at

Label: shipping address dispositon
Definition: A disposition of an address to be used to receive shipped goods
Example: The loading dock address for central receiving of an organization

Label: preferred address disposition
Definition: A disposition of an address to be displayed in most settings
Example: The address the organization displays most prominently in promotional materials

Label: architectural structure
Definition: A material entity that is a human made strcuture with firm connection between its foundation and the ground.
Example: Yankee Stadium, Stonehenge, The Shard, The Large Hadron Collider. The Great Wall of China
Editors Note: Perhaps identical to the term in OMRSE

Label: facility
Definition: An architectural structure that bears some function.
Example: Walt Disney World, Kennedy Space Center, Golden Gate Bridge
Editors Note: Perhaps identical to the term in OMRSE

Label: building
Definition: A permanent walled and roofed construction
Example: The Pentagon, The Leaning Tower of Pisa, The Gherkin, The Coliseum
Editors Note: Similar to the term in ENVRO, but based on 'architectural structure' in OMRSE

Label: geographical location
Definition: A place on the earth
Example: The Indian Ocean, Africa, Metropolitan France, West 57th Street
Editors Note: 1. Geographical locations are often confused with the entities that are located in those places.  For example, France is a country with several discontiguous geographical loctions.  Metropolitan France is a geographical location in Europe.  2. Unlike the GAZ term, this term is not a reference to a place on the earth, rather it is a place on the earth.

Label: geographical point
Definition: A point located on the earth
Example: The point with latitude 27.9881199 and longitude 86.9161989
Editors Note: 1. Since a point is smaller than a building, we say the point is located in a building.  The building is the location of the point.  2. Typically use ORG_0000004 to provide a lat/long value for the point.

Label: founding process
Definition: The process by which the organization was founded
Example: The United States government was founded by the constitutional convention process of 1787 resulting in a ratified constitution in 1790
Editors Note: The founding process might by a subproperty of a generic creation process if such a process ever appears at a higher level in the ontologies

Label: founding process boundary
Definition: The process boundary which defines the moment of creation of an orgnization.  Before the moment  the organization does not exist.  After the moment, the organization exists.
Example: The University of Bologna was founded in 1088.  Facebook was founded in 2004.

Label: dissolution process
Definition: The process by which an organization no longer exists.
Example: The German Democratic Republic (aka East Germany) ended in 1990.
Editors Note: There are many dissolution processes (merger, acquisition, discontinuation).  These can be added at a later date if needed.

Label: dissolution process boundary
Definition: The process boundary which marks the moment at which the organization no longer exists
Example: Duraspace ceased to exist on July 1, 2019
Editors Note: The dissolution process may have many steps and boundaries, such as ceasing operations, transfer of funds, dissolution of board.  These can be added at a later date if needed.

Label: campus
Definition: The geographic location consisting of the  grounds or property of a school, college, university, business, church, or hospital, often understood to include buildings and other structures.
Example: The campus of Oxford University, the campus of Microsoft in Redmonda, Washington, the NIH campus in Bethesda, Maryland.
